item.title: 11AECHE Class 1
item.description: Mixtures Properties of Matter (Term 1 Weeks 1-2) Definition of pure substance, common properties (melting/boiling point, hardness, density)

item.title: 11AECHE Class 10
item.description: [!NOTE] [[How to write a good method]] STAWA Set 4 Q4 Donâ€™t use moles unless youâ€™re doing calculations Use:

item.title: 11AECHE Class 11
item.description: The absorption spectra and emission spectra for each element superimpose exactly. Each elementâ€™s energy levels are slightly different, no two elements have the same spectra.

item.title: 11AECHE Class 12
item.description: Limitations of the flame test: Only small number of metal ions can be distinguished in this way as Bunsen flame is not hot enough to excite the electrons of many atoms.

item.title: 11AECHE Class 13
item.description: Electron configuration: First shell holds two elect rons Second shell holds 8 electrons Third shell holds 8 electrons (but has reserve space for 10 more) Note: Shells use the formula $2n^2$ as the total possible electrons that can be stored in that shell, where n represents the energy level notation.

item.title: 11AECHE Class 14
item.description: 11AECHE Class 14 Write electronic configuration using s,p,d notation for: S -> $1s^22s^22p^63s^23p^4$ $S^{-2}$ -> $1s^22s^22p^63s^23p^6$ Ar -> $1s^22s^22p^63s^23p^6$ The last 2 are “Isoelectronic” species/particles - not atoms, because ions are not atoms

item.title: 11AECHE Class 15
item.description: Check OneNote for homework Patterns in the Periodic table: Across the period, atomic radius will decrease. (increasing electrons will increase attraction between them and nucleus, decreasing radius)

item.title: 11AECHE Class 16
item.description: To determine whether something is polar or non-polar, you have to take into account the following: relative electronegativity of composite atoms shape of molecule Looking at symmetry of charges, not the symmetry of molecules.

item.title: 11AECHE Class 17
item.description: Bonding: Three distant substances: Na(s) - Metallic (metal only) NaCl (s) - Ionic (metal and non-metal) Cl_2 (g) - Covalent (non-metal only) Metalloids can have both metallic and non-metal properties.

item.title: 11AECHE Class 18
item.description: p-block elements gain one or more electrons to form stable anions. An ionic bond is the electrostatic force of attraction between oppositely charged ions.

item.title: 11AECHE Class 19
item.description: Electrical Conductivity What process takes place when sodium becomes a sodium ion $Na \rightarrow Na^{+}+ \bar e$ What happens to a chlorine atom when it becomes a chloride

item.title: 11AECHE Class 2
item.description: Objective 8 - Properties of matter: Element - only one type of atom, contain same number of protons Compound - a substance with 2 or more elements (different) chemically bonded together e.

item.title: 11AECHE Class 20
item.description: Covalent bond: A shared pair of electrons. There is an electrostatic force of attraction between the bonding pairs of electrons and the nuclei of the atoms at each side.

item.title: 11AECHE Class 21
item.description: VSEPR: The four pairs of electrons around a central atom repel each other. Pairs of electron arrange themselves so they are as far apart as possible.

item.title: 11AECHE Class 22
item.description: lol nothing happened [!NOTE] Post-Writing Commentary My interpretation of this statement is that things happened in the class, however nothing was note-worthy enough to write down.

item.title: 11AECHE Class 23
item.description: HOMEWORK: Revise atomic spectra Absorption and emissions spectra Structure of an atom Diamond vs Graphite:

item.title: 11AECHE Class 24
item.description: Revise Similarities/Differences between flame test and AAS REVISE WORKSHEET GIVEN BY MS PILLING [!NOTE] Post-writing Commentary Top ten notes of all time

item.title: 11AECHE Class 25
item.description: Empirical formula: Simplest whole number ratio of atoms (of each element) in a compound/molecule Molecular formula: Definite ratio, shows all atoms in a molecule

item.title: 11AECHE Class 26
item.description: Moles and Stoichiometry: Water: 0.24978 Cobalt: 0.035635 Sulfur: 0.035558 Oxygen: 0.1425 per O $\therefore$ the empirical formula of the hydrated compound is $CuSO_4.

item.title: 11AECHE Class 27
item.description: Types of Intermolecular Forces: Note: Intermolecular means between molecules. Are electrostatic (attraction between oppositely charged particles) Dispersion forces (van der Waals’ forces, London forces) Don’t call them weak, because it’s all relative Must show more than 1 molecule if drawing a diagram Dipole-dipole interaction Hydrogen bonding For molecules at a relatively similar size:

item.title: 11AECHE Class 28
item.description: Dispersion forces: Non-polar molecules/atoms have small, temporary, fluctuating dipoles due to random movement of electrons. A temporary dipole induces the dipole on other molecules/atoms.

item.title: 11AECHE Class 29
item.description: Intermolecular forces quiz: For the substances $CH_3CH_{2}OH, H_{2}O, CH_3CH_{2}CH_{3}$ and $CH_{3}COCH_{3}$, order in decreasing order the strengths of intermolecular forces.

item.title: 11AECHE Class 3
item.description: 11AECHE Class 3 [!NOTE] This is data from an experiment, with some images ported from Notion. I was sadly a Notion user for a long time :(

item.title: 11AECHE Class 30
item.description: Solution concentration Moles per litre (molarity) mol $L^{-1}$: $c = \frac{n}{v}$ c is the concentration of solute in moles per litre (mol L-1)

item.title: 11AECHE Class 31
item.description: Substances that do not dissolve in water: The strengths of ionic bonding is so great that ion dipole forces that form are not enough to break it.

item.title: 11AECHE Class 32
item.description: Solubility Curves: Solubility curves show the solubility of substances as temperature changes. Generally, the solubility of ionic solids increases with temperature.

item.title: 11AECHE Class 33
item.description: Gas Chromatography: GC is used widely in many analytical laboratories, including forensic police labs, synthetic chemical labs, and drug testing labs.

item.title: 11AECHE Class 34
item.description: Acids: pH < 7 $[H^{+}]> [OH^{-}]$ Turn universal indicators (UI(Ethan Widjaja made it up)(Ms Pilling did as well)) red.

item.title: 11AECHE Class 35
item.description: 11AECHE Class 35 BrÃ¸nstedâ€“Lowry model: Acids are proton donors e.g. HCl can ionise and produce hydrogen ions in aqueous solution

item.title: 11AECHE Class 36
item.description: 11AECHE Class 36 Acid + Bases 1 2 Arrhenius acid: A substance that ionises into hydrogen ions in an **aqueous solution** e.

item.title: 11AECHE Class 37
item.description: 11AECHE Class 37 Definition of pH: $-log[H^+]$ $[H^+]$ concentration in mol L$^{-1}$ Therefore, $[H^{+}]=10^{-pH}$ DONT USE pOH MS PILLING DOES NOT LIKE pOH

item.title: 11AECHE Class 38
item.description: 1 mole of any gas will occupy 22.71 L at STP (Standard temperature and pressures) STP: T = 0.0 $\degree$ C (273.

item.title: 11AECHE Class 39
item.description: Organic Chemistry: Refers to carbon compounds Excludes molecules such as $CO_2$, $H_2CO_3$ ane suggests that the compound is saturated.

item.title: 11AECHE Class 4
item.description: Methods of Separation: Objectives: 5 (Essential skills). Write and use balanced chemical equations to represent chemical reactions Explain the relationship between the identity and relative amounts of substances om a solution, and its properties.

item.title: 11AECHE Class 40
item.description: C-C and C-H bonds are considered non-polar. Complete combustion happens when oxygen in excess, this is the main form of combustion

item.title: 11AECHE Class 41
item.description: Properties of Alkanes 3-ethylhexane C8H18 C4H9 Chemical Properties: Combustion, alkanes are commonly used as fuels. Substitution reaction $C_2H_6$ + $Br_2$ $\rightarrow (UV light)$ $C_2H_5Br$ + $HBr$ In the absence of light, reaction does not occur.

item.title: 11AECHE Class 42
item.description: Alkenes: unsaturated hydrocarbons, containing a single double bond between Carbon atoms Higher ratio of carbon to hydrogen More double bonds means its not a alkene.

item.title: 11AECHE Class 43
item.description: Enthalpy - thermal energy at constant pressure Chemical reactions: reactant $\rightarrow$ products Reactants: breaking bonds Products: forming bonds Energy is needed to overcome electrostatic force of attraction and break bonds.

item.title: 11AECHE Class 44
item.description: Particles need minimum amount of energy to collide successfully and react, this is called activation energy. We try to increase rate of reaction because its useful.

item.title: 11AECHE Class 45
item.description: Empirical Formula for combustion: $C_xH_yO_{z}+ (x+y-z)O_{2} \rightarrow xCO_{2} + \frac{1}{2}yH_2O$ The Ideal Gas Law is used to determine the molar mass and from that the molecular formula

item.title: 11AECHE Class 5
item.description: [!NOTE] The following are answers to questions done in class, given by Ms Pilling. $Na_2CO_{3(aq)}+ 2HCl_{(aq)} \rightarrow 2NaCl_{(aq)} + CO_{2(g)} + H_2O_{(l)} \ \checkmark$

item.title: 11AECHE Class 6
item.description: Crystallisation occurs when the solution solvent evaporates, and the concentration of the solute reaches saturation point. At this stage, the solute begins to precipitate out of solution.

item.title: Chemistry Stoichiometry Notes
item.description: Before starting to learn about stoichiometry, think about this little analogy. Let’s say I have two cubes, one being 100 grams of pure Carbon, and another being 100 grams of Aluminium.

item.title: Chromatography
item.description: Chromatography Chromatography is a laboratory technique for separation and identification. Types of Chromatography include: GC/GLC - Gas (Liquid) Chromatography HPLC - High Performance Liquid Chromatography Paper Chromatography TLC - Thin Layered Chromatography Column Chromatography In all examples of chromatography:

item.title: Organic Chem Notes
item.description: Key Definitions Organic Chemistry: The study of carbon-containing compounds (e.g. $CH_4$) Fractional Distillation: Short Answer: A type of distillation (separation technique for miscible(dissolve in each other) liquids), that utilises slight differences in boiling points.

item.title: Pilling Calculation Questions
item.description: Calculate number of ions in 5.25g of aluminium sulfate? $Al_{2}(SO_{4})_{3} \to 5$ ions $n = \frac{m}{M}, \therefore n(Al_{2}(SO_{4}){3}) = \frac{5.25}{2 \times 26.

item.title: Properties of matter
item.description: Properties of matter Notes my generic notes: Objective 8 - Properties of matter: Element - The simplest kind of substance that cannot be broken down into anything simpler.

item.title: R-AECHE-46
item.description: Oxidation is Loss, Reduction is Reduced OILRIG We need to identify when a substance is oxidised or reduced, this is assisted via the use of oxidation numbers.

item.title: R-AECHE-47
item.description: Corrosion of Metals The degradation of metals due to an electrochemical process. Actually refers to iron. Influences on corrosion: Impurities Can either protect iron or enhance rate of corrosion.

item.title: The Periodic Table
item.description: The Periodic Table Period number is equal the the electron shell that an element’s valency electrons occupy. E.g. in period 2, the valence electrons are on the n = 2 shells.

item.description: sadly this exists Key Messages + 1 Section Strict water quality controls are in place to protect human health and aquatic ecosystems from chemical and biological pollutants.
